result of people seeking medical attention earlier in their disease trajectory. policy to ban smoking in many public areas has resulted in a reduction in smoking rates over the past 35 years, from 23.3% in 1982 to 10.0% in 2017 in Hong Kong [28]. a significant decline in HbA1c values at diagnosis of type 2 diabetes from 2002 to 2011, possibly reflecting proactive case finding and earlier detection. the incidence of type 2 diabetes may be higher in east Asians than in europeans. low body weight is linked to poorer pancreatic beta cell reserve. the excess of 21,000 new cases of type 2 diabetes in 2004 compared with 2003 might be due to heightened health vigilance at the aftermath of the epidemic. the categorisation of type 1 and type 2 diabetes was based on an algorithm rather than direct inspection of the clinical notes. the absence of confirmatory tests such as anti-islet cell antibodies or C-peptide levels could lead to incorrect differentiation of type 1 and type 2 diabetes. the impact on incidence of type 2 diabetes was probably minimal. in areas with a high burden of type 1 diabetes, the incidence appeared to have stabilised over the past decade [9,10,11]. Conversely, the incidence of type 1 diabetes has continued to rise in places of low disease prevalence, including East Asia [12,13]. obesity rose from 11.6% in the mid-1990s to 16.7% in 2005 [16]. prevalence was 17.6% in primary school students and 19.9% in secondary school students in the last estimation in 2018 [17]. in contrast to the rising trend of childhood-onset type 1 diabetes, the incidence of adult-onset type 1 diabetes has not increased. prevalence of type 2 diabetes has been stable in men and has declined in women since the mid-1990s [23,24], which is attributable to a series of government-led health promotion initiatives targeting healthier lifestyles. the absence of a rise might reflect levelling off in exposure to risk factors. alangh and colleagues reported 10-year secular trends in diabetes incidence in canada. incidence increased moderately by 24% in the european population compared with a 15-fold increase in the Chinese population by 2005. excess of 21,000 new cases of type 2 diabetes in 2004 compared with 2003 could be due to heightened health vigilance at the aftermath of the epidemic. the modest dip in the number of new cases in the ensuing 3 years (from 2005 to 2007) could support earlier identification of cases during the transitory period, leaving fewer cases to be detected. misclassifying type 1 diabetes would significantly inflate the incidence of type 1 diabetes, whereas the impact on incidence of type 2 diabetes was probably minimal. despite limitations in details of the extracted information, we could not discern patients with other aetiologies of diabetes. number of new cases of type 2 diabetes by year in the Hong Kong Diabetes Surveillance Database, 2002–2015. 158.4KB, tif) S3 Fig. Incidence trends of type 2 diabetes in boys aged 20 years using restricted cubic spline. additional data file (85KB, doc).
